title: Life Science HiSET S.1.2 (Q19)
prompt:
A codon is a series of three nucleotides in a portion of a nucleic acid molecule such as RNA or DNA. In DNA, there are four nucleotide bases: adenine (A), cytosine (C), guanine (G), thymine (T).

How many possible three-nucleotide codons are there, using these four nucleotide bases?
feedback: Any of the four nucleotide bases can be in any position in the three-nucleotide series. To find the number of permutations of three nucleotides, raise the number of nucleotides (4) to the power of the number of positions in the codon (3). The number of possible codons is 43, or 64.
